temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content: Salmonella can grow at temperatures between 5°C and 47°C, although its optimal temperature range is 35 to 37°C. It cannot grow at temperatures exceeding 47°C, but it can survive at higher temperatures of up to 70°C. Below 5°C, Salmonella does not grow but can survive freezing.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: Salmonella is a facultative anaerobe, meaning that it uses oxygen, but is capable of switching to fermentation if oxygen is absent.

ph.title: pH
ph.content: Salmonella cannot survive in environments with a pH below 4.0 or above 9.0: it grows optimally in environments with a pH between 6.5 and 7.5.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: Salmonella can grow in environments (food) with water activity exceeding 0.94 and an optimum water activity level of around 0.99; it can survive in dried foods, with low water activity, for years.

salinity.title: Salinity
salinity.content: Although Salmonella is generally inhibited in the presence of 3 to 4% sodium chloride, bacterial salt tolerance increases with increasing temperatures in the range of 10 to 30°C.
